en.comp:
Read the passage given below and answer the question that follow by selecting the correct / most appropriate option:

1. When Nelson Mandela was sentenced to life imprisonment in 1964, the apartheid government believed he would disappear into obscurity. Everything possible was done to cut his contact with the outside world. Newspapers, publications and radio stations were banned from using his image or quoting him. He could write to his wife just once every six months. Denied access, the authorities reasoned, his radical views would certainly fade away. Or so they thought.

2. Yet, when he was released from prison 27 years later, the country exploded with joy. Rather than destroy his image, the news blackout had created a myth, an icon who had willingly paid the price to ensure equal opportunity for all. For South Africans, his appearance at the gates of Victor Verster Prison near Cape Town on February 11, 1990 was an odd experience. Many had no idea what he looked like. The sight of a tall slim man, smiling as he walked out of prison, had an electrifying effect on the thousands waiting to see Mandela, a man who at his trial had said that his fight against oppression of any kind was a cause "for which I am prepared to die...".

3. Later, when Mandela stood outside the Cape Town City Hall to address the thousands who had come to see him, his message was not one of anger or revenge, but of reconciliation and peace. Madiba, as he was affectionately called, was free, but his task of universal voting and racial harmony had not yet begun.

Our lives are one big puzzle,

We don't know how many pieces we've got.

There are people that fit in quite nicely,

So you won't have to look back when it's over,

And realise you've left out the sun.

<strong>&#39;A&nbsp;<u> fossil </u>is the remains of an animal or a plant&#39;. The underlined word is a/an :</strong>
en.comp:
Read the passage given below and answer the question that follow by selecting the correct/ most appropriate option :

1. A fossil is the remains of an animal or a plant which is no longer living. It has been dead for many years and only a part of it is left today. This part is called a fossil. For example, when a shellfish dies, the soft part of the body will soon rot. But the shell of the organism which is hard and made of calcium, will remain. The shell sinks into the sand at the bottom of the sea. Many years pass and the sand changes into sandstone. We dig down into the sandstone, we find fossils. So, fossils are nothing but the hardened traces of animals or plants buried in the earth.

2. Fossils are a good source of study to palaeontologists (scientists who study fossils). By studying them, they learn about the changes that occurred on the earth million years ago. For example, finding a shellfish fossil in a mountainous region, a scientist may conclude that the area was once under sea water. Similarly, finding fossils of tropical plants in Greenland, one may conclude that this landmass once had a different climate other than the present one.

3. Besides fossils of animals, one may find fossils of plants too. Trees and plants near lakes and streams often fall into the water and subsequently get buried in the soft mud. Finally, after many long years, the tree changes from wood into fossil. Thus, fossils are a great source of interest to observe and study not only for scientists but for others also.

The shell sinks into the sand at the bottom of the sea. Many years pass and the sand changes into sandstone. We dig down into the sandstone, we find fossils. So, fossils are nothing but the hardened traces of animals or plants buried in the earth.

2. Fossils are a good source of study to palaeontologists (scientists who study fossils). By studying them, they learn about the changes that occurred on the earth million years ago. For example, finding a shellfish fossil in a mountainous region, a scientist may conclude that the area was once under sea water. Similarly, finding fossils of tropical plants in Greenland, one may conclude that this landmass once had a different climate other than the present one.

3. Besides fossils of animals, one may find fossils of plants too. Trees and plants near lakes and streams often fall into the water and subsequently get buried in the soft mud. Finally, after many long years, the tree changes from wood into fossil. Thus, fossils are a great source of interest to observe and study not only for scientists but for others also.

en.value: <strong>&#39;He was <u>all right</u> within a week.&#39; The underlined words in this sentence are which part of speech?</strong>
en.comp:
Read the passage given below and answer the question that follow by selecting the correct/ most appropriate option:

1. After the accident, a car from the hospital took Krishna to hospital. The two men carried him to a bed and put him in it carefully. Soon a nurse and a doctor came. The nurse wrote his name and address in a book. The doctor took the bandage off Krishna's arm, looked at it carefully and put his hand on it. He said, "The arm is broken." He said to the nurse, "Give him some tea to drink." Then he said to Krishna, "Do not worry, we will do something just now. You will be alright soon!" Krishna was a little cheered up and said, "Thank you, doctor."

2. The nurse gave him tea to drink and covered him with a warm cloth. The doctor gave him an injection to lessen his pain. He tied some bandages and applied plaster. Krishna's arm pained him a lot and he requested the doctor to look at it. The doctor told the nurse to give another injection. After this Krishna could sleep well. While Krishna was in the hospital, many of his friends came to see him. Whenever his father and mother came to visit him, they brought some fruit, milk and books. There were several other persons suffering from different diseases in Krishna's room. He was all right within a week and went home after greeting his room fellows.
